source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Maximum clad strains were found at about $1 1 2 5 \ \mathrm { K } ,$ just below the $\pmb { \alpha }$ to $\beta$ transus, and could exceed $100 \%$ diameter increase.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: The consensus that eventually emerged was that the maximum local blockage would be of the order of $90 \%$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Many experiments confirmed this as an upper bound, with a low probability of blockage exceeding $60 \%$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Clad temperature transients achieved the required levels of about $1 1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { \bf K }$

evidence_span: In worst cases, there could be up to a 10-s delay in the cooling of blocked regions compared with by-pass regions, and the maximum peak temperature difference was 50 to $1 0 0 ~ \mathbf { K }$ , although the norm was zero or negative.
